body: Bumper Cars Cobble Hill is a neighborhood of old brownstones and narrow streets. It also has a hospital and nursing home whose employees often wait in their cars and save spaces for friends on the next shift -- an annoying but not illegal practice. What must be illegal, though, is cramming one's car into too small a space. Having witnessed this one
title: COMPLAINT BOX; And Another Thing...

author: E-mail: citycritic@nytimes.com
body: The space is instantly familiar, and instantly depressing. With its fluorescent lights, linoleum counters and stale air, it could pass for a Department of Motor Vehicles office or a passport agency. But it's the Kensington Post Office in Brooklyn, which has been reviled by many as the worst in New York City. Late December is high season for the
title: CITY CRITIC; Bad Post Office. Good Post Office.

body: MENORAH REMOVAL Stirs Community On Sunday afternoon, about a dozen families gathered at the Key Food supermarket in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, to light a menorah in celebration of Hanukkah. By Monday, the menorah had vanished. Residents began to wonder whether anti-Semitism might have had something to do with its disappearance. A letter from Moshe
title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: THE house that Michael and Lori Hiller planned to buy in South Park Slope, Brooklyn, was a good size for the neighborhood, and on a pleasant block. But then a problem developed with the building's certificate of occupancy. Since Mrs. Hiller had been the bigger fan of Park Slope, it was Mr. Hiller who had more zest for a new search. He found himself
title: LIVING IN | DITMAS PARK, BROOKLYN; Moved for the Space; Stayed for the Food

body: HELEN PEARLSTEIN, an ebullient blonde in her 60s, may not be the single best-known resident of Concord Village, the Brooklyn co-op where she has lived for nearly a quarter of a century. title: HABITATS; A Makeover As Homage To the Past

body: Starting this week, Susan Coronel, a day care owner, plans to leave her home in Ridgewood, Queens, most days at 6:45 a.m. with her 5-year-old son, Benjamin, and drive 10 minutes to Bushwick, Brooklyn. title: BIG CITY; Going the Distance to Get A Child to a Magnet School

body: It's said that every vote counts. This is particularly true of a number of City Council races in New York City on Sept. 15, when a few hundred votes could determine who will occupy a front-row seat in city government. title: EDITORIAL; For New York City Council

body: On a rainy morning in April, Lisa Feuer took the subway to the Brooklyn Dojo, a martial-arts studio where she was scheduled to teach a mommy-baby yoga class. Outside, streams of water poured from awnings into the collars of passers-by. When she got to the studio, Feuer shook out her umbrella and picked out music from her iPhone to play for the
title: What happened to all those liberated, self-reliant, self-branded free agents?

body: Thirty-four students were injured Friday morning when a grate gave way under them as they stood outside a Brooklyn school for graduation photographs, the authorities said. Thirteen of the injured students were taken to Maimonides Medical Center, 12 were taken to Lutheran Medical Center, 5 were taken to New York Methodist Hospital and 4 were
title: 34 Children Are Hurt as Grate Collapses

author: Albert Fayngold, a painter, is a lecturer on Russian and comparative literature at Baruch College. He is currently enrolled in the Writers' Institute program at the CUNY Graduate Center.
body: IN the summer of 1992, I was 21 and it cost $1.25 to ride the subway. The Soviet Union had been dead for nearly a year, and from the window of the F train heading from the Kensington section of Brooklyn into the city, I peered at the Lower Manhattan skyline and beyond it to my lost home across the ocean. I was a Lot's wife in pants. Those were
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; The Call of Kiev

body: The Hunt column last Sunday, about the search by two ballet dancers for an apartment to buy in Manhattan, misidentified, at one point, the street in Kensington, Brooklyn, where the couple's previous co-op was located. As noted earlier in the article, it was on Ocean Parkway, not Ocean Avenue.
title: CORRECTIONS

body: Corrections Appended WHEN they lived on Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn, Kristi Boone and Isaac Stappas -- dancers for American Ballet Theater -- had such a time-consuming trip home from work that they bought a car. After performing until, say, 11 p.m.; changing into street clothes; stepping out the stage door; and maybe signing some autographs, they
title: THE HUNT; A New Performance on 94th Street

body: IN scene after scene in ''Two Lovers,'' the new movie starring Gwyneth Paltrow and Joaquin Phoenix as a star-crossed couple, the Brooklyn neighborhood of Brighton Beach is on lush display. The camera lingers affectionately on Brighton Cleaners on Coney Island Avenue, on Cafe Restaurant Volna, which sits opposite the Boardwalk, and on the Boardwalk
title: BRIGHTON BEACH; Brighton Beach, N.J.

body: As resistance to foreclosure evictions grows among homeowners, community leaders and some law enforcement officials, a broad civil disobedience campaign is starting in New York and other cities to support families who refuse orders to vacate their homes. The community organizing group Acorn unveiled the campaign with a spirited rally on Friday at a
title: A Bid to Link Arms Against Eviction

body: WHEN strangers approach, there's a fierce bark behind the closed door of the Blitz family's 1899 American Foursquare house in Kensington, Brooklyn. But on close inspection, the dog, Magda, turns out to be just 10 inches tall, and pretty enough to be carried around in a socialite's Louis Vuitton bag. ''She's a Can Hardly,'' said Dori Dietz Blitz.
title: HABITATS | KENSINGTON, BROOKLYN; Elbow Room and Elbow Grease

body: THERE are so many things you can't do in the big, bad city, and you'd think that one of them would be climbing down a manhole when you're not an employee of the Department of Transportation or the Metropolitan Transportation Authority or Con Edison. But you would be wrong. Thanks to Bob Diamond, the man who rediscovered a 19th-century Atlantic
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; The Tunnel Rats of Atlantic Avenue

body: There were days when Patricia Campbell could not get out of bed. Over the course of two years, she had fallen from her $70,000-per-year dream job to the doldrums of on-again-off-again work. She was subsisting on a diet of cereal, and her cats -- Priscilla, Baby Boy and Pandora -- seemed to be the only ones who cared about her plight. As Ms.
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Coping With the Loss of Steady Work

author: E-mail: susan.dominus@nytimes.com
body: They didn't give Frank Perri the nickname Buzz back in high school because he ran fast, or because he liked to mess around with slot cars, the miniature electric vehicles that zoom around a track. They called him Buzz because he was a star high jumper, and that was the sound the appreciative crowd made when he soared over a pole six feet off the
title: BIG CITY; The Buzz in Brooklyn Is Still All About Speed
